text: Rosalie "Rosie" Méndez Hamlin (July 21, 1945 – March 30, 2017) was an American singer-songwriter. She was the frontwoman of the group Rosie and the Originals. She was born in Klamath Falls, Oregon, but was raised in Anchorage, Alaska. Hamlin was best known for the 1960 song "Angel Baby", which became a Top 40 hit in 1961 when Hamlin was only fifteen years old. She retired from the music industry in 1963. Hamlin's "Angel Baby" was covered by several artists, including Linda Ronstadt and John Lennon, who cited Hamlin as one of his favorite singers. She was the first Latina to be honored by the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, as well as the first Latina to appear on Dick Clark's American Bandstand in 1961. Hamlin died on March 30, 2017 in Belen, New Mexico from a long-illness at the age of 71. ==References== ==Other websites== * Category:1945 births Category:2017 deaths Category:American singer-songwriters Category:American pianists Category:Musicians from Oregon Category:Singers from Oregon Category:Singers from Alaska Category:Writers from Anchorage, Alaska Category:Musicians from Anchorage, Alaska Category:Disease-related deaths in New Mexico
title: Rosie Hamlin
